short_description: Explore Bangladesh, the land of rivers and Bengal tigers, where vibrant culture meets natural beauty. Discover the Sundarbans mangrove forest, ancient mosques, bustling cities, tea plantations, and experience the warm hospitality of the Bengali people.

health.tap_water_safety: Not safe to drink - bottled or filtered water is recommended
alcohol_info: It is prohibited to sell, serve, or offer alcohol beverages to anyone under the age of 21
Alcohol can only be purchased from licensed hotels and restaurants
Public consumption of alcohol is restricted due to Islamic cultural norms

tipping.hotels: Small tips for porters and housekeeping are appreciated
tipping.guides: 10% tip is appreciated for tour guides
tipping.restaurants: 10% tip is customary for good service, though not always expected
tipping.taxis: Rounding up the fare is common

weather.title: Bangladesh has a tropical monsoon climate with three distinct seasons: a hot, dry summer from March to May; a hot, humid monsoon season from June to October; and a cool, dry winter from November to February.

when_to_visit.title: Winter
when_to_visit.short_description: Cool and dry weather, making this the best time to visit. Perfect for exploring cities, visiting historic sites, and wildlife safaris in the Sundarbans. Ideal conditions for sightseeing and outdoor activities

when_to_visit.title: Spring
when_to_visit.short_description: Hot and dry weather before the monsoon. Still manageable for travel, but be prepared for high temperatures. Good time to visit tea plantations in Sylhet and explore cultural sites

when_to_visit.title: Monsoon Season
when_to_visit.short_description: Heavy rainfall and high humidity. Challenging conditions for travel, with flooding possible. Not ideal for most tourists, though the countryside is lush and green

weather.best_time: The best time to visit Bangladesh is during the winter months from November to February when the weather is cool and dry, making it ideal for exploring cities, historic sites, wildlife safaris in the Sundarbans, and outdoor activities
